You also know that the last two digits of the registration do not form a number. Which of these statements could be correct? Choices:  (a) The only letters on the registration are A, B, C.  (b) The registration number has 6 letters.  (c) The 3rd digit after the registration number is a.  (d) The 4th digit after the registration number has been changed.  (e) The 5 letter after the registration number has not changed.<n><n>### Response:(d) The 4 digit after the registration number may change without any notification to the airline.<n><n>### Example:The flight EWA783 left on time from New York JFK's 9:40am flight and landed on time in Los Angeles at 13:30.The same plane returns to New York JFK airport at 8:30am.<n><n>### Note:In the above example, the plane's destination is New York, but the departure time is 8:30 am.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>I would use a string to identify which type of city the plane is going to. Then use a decision making structure to verify if the flight is local. <n>The if or else if statement will be needed to differentiate whether we are the departure part or return part.<n><n>### If(string equals to string X){return local flight}<n><n><n><n>### Example:-I will use 2 if/else statement. If the flight from where it is departing is Los Angeles, and it is arriving at New York JFK, it is a local plane. If the flight from Los Angeles it is arriving at any other city like Boston, it is a long-distance flight.<n><n>### if(string.equals(LAX)){return Los Angeles=local flight}<n><n>### else{return

He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:The drug kingpin told his man to run errands, this was code to go to all the dealers to do what they had? Choices:  A: park B: make time for C: receive instructions D: take money E: leave work<n><n>### Response:		A<n>

There are no seafood restaurant in North East. Coastal city, Boston does not provide restaurants with seafood. A, B, C, D. Only 'D', east coast of North America provides restaurant with seafood for its guests.

How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:What state south of Kentucky and north of Alabama will you find people playing the fiddle? Choices:  A: alabama B: tennessee C: violin case D: music store E: bow and strings<n><n>### Response:		Answer  : Stringcase<n><n>### Explaination:<n>Ask a simple question<n><n>### Input and Output:<n>Q: Which string instrument is found exclusively in Kentucky?<n><n>A: Answer "violin case"<n><n>### Explain and test your logic:<n>Because you know that the instruments for the music store can all the "A", "B", "C", and "D" answers. You need to create an exclusion statement to remove the stringed instrument case and the fiddle because they would not be classified as the fiddle instrument. Then you need to add in the violin instrument since it can be found in Kentucky.<n><n>### Logic:<n>1. Question: Where will you find people playing a fiddle?<n>2. Choices: Alabemya, Kentucky, violin case, music store, bow, and strings<n>3. Choice list removed: bow and strings, (Removed because they can be found outside of Kentucky)<n>4. Choices: Kentucky, Alabama, Violin case, (Add the list to include the fiddle instrument)

He had trouble telling it from what? Choices:  A: reality B: imagination C: dreamworker D: nightmare E: awake<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following free response question using complete sentences.<n><n>### Question: The word "question" can be found in all of the sentences below. Can you think of another example in which the word "question" can also be found?<n><n>Question One: In a classroom of 25 students, 10 students were interviewed. Out of these 10 students 3 students said that they plan on using this particular math strategy tomorrow and 7 students indicated that they had used the same math strategy yesterday. However, no student indicated that they plan on using the same math strategy for a third consecutive day. What is the sample space?<n>Answer: Every combination of the 3 students that were interviewed used the same math strategy the day before and the remaining 7 students that were interviewed did not use the same math strategy at all, thus there are five outcomes<n><n>Question Two: In the same classroom as above, 10 students are also interviewed. The math teacher finds a question, "Will the following math problem be too difficult for some of your students?" What is the probability that the math teacher will receive a "yes" response?<n>Answer: There are 20 outcomes in which there is the potential of the math teacher receiving the "yes" response. Thus, the probability of receiving the "yes" is 1/20.<n><n>Question Three: You are playing a game of basketball with your friend. The two of you make $5 bets to see who can make the more shots first. You shoot 60 shots and your friend shoots 25 shots. What is the probability that you will win this bet?<n>Answer: There is a total of 85 outcomes and there are a total of 5 bets, thus, the probability of winning the bet is 5/85.<n><n>Question Four: You and your friends are in a pool tournament. You are playing your semi-final match versus your friend. There are three rounds of play to decide winner. Your current game score is 28-16. If they are to continue playing and you win 7 games to his 2, what is the probability of you winning the final against your friend?<n>Answer: There exists three total outcomes and 24 possible ways of winning the final, so the probability is 24/3.<n><n>##

He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:At the end of your meal what will a waiter do? Choices:  A: serve food B: eat C: set table D: serve meal E: present bill<n><n>### Response:		 A <n><n>### Input:"Hello! How can I help you?" Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:John came to see Sam and Sam kicked him out.  Sam didn't like company.  He prefered what? Choices:  A: you B: abbreviation C: solitude D: loneliness E: alone<n><n>### Response:		 E<n><n><br><n><n>### Instructions: <n>The computer has three parts: the display, processor, and memory. <n><n>* The display makes decitions on what information to show you.<n>* The processor is what handles all of the functions you do on the computer as well as what allows your computer to work.<n>* The memory is what handles all the information that the computer saves. <n><n>Each component works with the other to complete the computing process. <n><n><br> <br><n><n>## Computer Hardware:<n><n>* Hardware is what you physically see when you open or turn on your computer.<n>* Some examples of computer hardware are (but not limited to): - the mouse - the monitor - your computer<n>  * The mouse is an input device that allows the user to move or click buttons for a variety of function. <n>  * The monitor is an output device that allows the user use to see anything that is being displayed. <n>  * Your computer is an output device where you can input information as well as see what you have created or accessed.<n>* Software is what allows the computer to work.<n>  * It's not an actual program or piece of information, but instead what a program actually "is". <n><n>## Input Devices: <n>* <n>  * ___1____: The mouse<n>  * ___2____: The keyboard<n><n>## Output Devices: <n><n>* <n> <n>  * ____1___:  ______2_____<n><n>##  Types of Software:  <n><n>* System Software is used to open programs on the computer as well has to handle all of the internal computations. <n>  * <n>    * Examples of system software include: <n>      * ____3___ - ___4____<n>* Application Software is what is actually used to perform tasks on the computer.<n>  * <n>  *  ___5______ <n>  *  Examples of application software include: <n>    * <n>    <n>      <n>      * ____5_ - _______6__<n><n>##  Programming Languages:<n><n>* Assembly language and C++ both provide machine-level representations that can be directly executed by the CPU.<n>  * 5_____ 6_____<n>    * 7 __ 8___ <n>  *

However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. When he donates a fourth, he has left with 20 remaining books. <n>Cameron on the other hand has 30 books. Since he donates a third, he ends up with 12 books as his total amount. <n>So, the total amount that they now have together is 22<n><n>### Output:<n><n>Happy holidays, everyone!<n>![](/images/homepage/greeting.png)<n><n>### Instructions<n>Input: A mother and her son both work and receive a paycheck of $34.60. At the restaurant, she collects $138.55 per Sunday. The son worked at a gas station for the entire week and collected $633.30, and gave 1/3 of it to the church every Sunday. She goes into the kitchen and finds:<n><n>- 6 cups of rice<n>- 3 cups of onions<n>- 2 pumpkins<n>- 1 pound of peanut butter<n>- 7 pounds of apples<n>- 1 banana<n>- 11 avocados<n>- 1 carrot<n>- 1 jar of pickles<n>- 7 oranges<n>- 1 gallon of milk<n><n>There is a basket of vegetables and fruit on the kitchen table.<n><n>To make her dish, Gina grabs a box, places the vegetables and fruit in it, and then places the box on the kitchen table next to the pickles. She adds three apples, the onions, a tablespoon of pickles, the pumpkin, the milk and the rice from the cupboard.<n><n>Next, she adds two cups of peanut butters, some pickles and bananas from the container in the refrigerator, and grabs the vegetables and fruit that is stored in the fridge. She adds two oranges from the fruit basket, the rice from the stove, the carrot and half of the pickles from the pickle jar.<n><n>She uses the knives and cuts the carrot and peels the oranges that are stored in the fruit basket. She adds the knife and carrot and peel to the bin in the kitchen on the far right. She adds the vegetables and fruit from the far left. She places the bin on top of the bin on the far right.<n><n>Then, she adds a piece of the fruit basket to the top bin on the far right that already has a piece of vegetables and fruit inside it. She makes sure that the piece of fruit is not over the top by one-third of the bin.<n><n>Finally, Gina removes a mug from on top of the sink and fills it with the vegetables. She puts the mug back onto the kitchen table.<n>How many pieces of fruit did Gina use to make her dish?<n><n>Answer: 7
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:Traveling underwater has many dangers, such as low visibility causing what? Choices:  A: disorientation B: due to C: meeting new people D: getting somewhere E: relocation<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input Traveling on an airplane may make you feel as if you are getting somewhere, but if the plane crashes, do you still really get somewhere?<n><n>### Response C<n><n>

After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:Someone lacking immortality will one day be? Choices:  A: kick the bucket B: mortal C: dead D: can die E: dying<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### D<n><n>#### Response Explanation:<n>The choice 'kick the bucket' is in reference to dying or when on the moon one might be 'out of gas':<n><n>Kick the bucket. The _bucket_ refers to something's being _empty_ or _emptied_. The expression has two meanings depending on its context. When used with _up_ or _down_, it means that something has ended, as in, "He's down for the count, so just kick the bucket." To _kick the bucket_ also means to die, especially when referring to a person who is wealthy and is dying in the _hospital_ : "The man's dying, you know, and he and his wife are living on a _sinking ship_. They need to sell the estate and sell some of the _valuables_. I mean, they can't just get rid of the buck-and-a-half-a-ton _slippers_ and the _silver goblets_, can they, my _dear_?" (Bill Bryson)<n><n>The choice'moral' is a morale that is connected to a philosophy, an action or an idea in general.<n><n>Moral. n. _adj_ 1. of or _relating to a set of principles governing the conduct of an _individual_ or group. 'It is a _moral duty_ for those who can afford to help the poor, to do so.'<n><n>'The moral standards of the school were very _high_.'<n><n>'Education should be _moral_ as well as academic.'<n><n>'He was a good man but had no _moral_ sense.'<n><n>'We are supposed to follow the moral teachings of Jesus.'<n><n>'The laws were not enough to _control_ his _moral_ sense.<n><n>2.1. used in exhortations especially when the _purpose_ is to _encourage_ _others_ to follow a _particular set of principles_. 'Our aim must be to keep the country true to its _moral standards_.'<n><n>#### D<n>

She opened it for her cousin who said that she should go out immediately because of the fog, to which she answered that the fog would not hurt an old woman like her. So I sent for a carriage and we went to my landlady to tell her to keep an eye on her hens. It was raining hard when we went to the cemetery. Some women were going past, carrying a little body on a bier. When they had gone farther, something fell down and hit against my ankle; it was a gold chain, and it had two big keys hanging to it. When the body was brought into the vault, she lifted her gown and showed the legs of the little thing. There was no face on it, but on the legs were two deep gashes. That was strange! Then she began to cry bitterly.<n><n>### Output:A small girl was being buried.

After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:What place of work might you find a hairpin? Choices:  A: hair salon B: hair of woman C: barber shop D: pincushion E: woman's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Answer A:<n>\- The hair salon is the best fitting option. It is a place where people go to get their hair done. It's obvious that hair is the thing that attracts clients (it's obvious that it's also the most common hair concern for clients), so a pin for their appointment would make sense.<n><n>#### Answer B:<n>\- The barber shop is out. Barbers don't do that much with hair and the client's hair isn't even their concern. They cut the hair and then give the client a haircut. For some reason, a pin for their appointment wouldn't make much sense there.<n><n>#### Answer C:<n>\- A pincushion seems like an odd choice. If you're going to use a pin for your hair anyway, you might as well just go to the hair salon.<n><n>#### Answer D:<n>\- The only woman who's having her hair done at the library is the librarian, so it's definitely not for her. This choice would also be weird since it seems as if hair is not really a focus at the library.<n><n>#### Answer E:<n>\- The woman who's having their hair done at the library has more than one hair because they have both a beard and a mustache. This means that if you took a hairpin to the library to use with their hair, it would be either for their beard or their mustache. It also means that you don't need a pin for their hair.<n><n>### Input :The time for when the class to finish<n><n>### Response<n>#### Answer A: 2148<n>\- This question asks which time has the most of the total time the class is scheduled to be over by. So if the class is scheduled to end at 3:25pm, the entire question is about "which time is closer to 3:30pm?" If you subtract 3:25 from every time, there are no times that go under 2:00 and under 2:10, so anything after 2:09 can't count as the answer.<n><n>1. 2:00 is at most 29 minutes, but 3:29 is at most 28 minutes (25+3=28)<n>2. 2:09

He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:John enjoyed his time visiting the museum.  He wanted to spend more time there, so that he could study the exhibits more.   He was a very academic person and loved doing what? Choices:  A: tired feet B: gaining knowledge C: back pain D: being bored E: pondering<n><n>### Response:		<n>John visited John's favorite museum, but he felt he could've spent more time there. He loved learning and going to school, but his time in the museums encouraged him to go to school because he had more opportunities to learn more.<n>### Instruction/ Delivery:<n>Input: John enjoyed his time visiting John’s favorite museum. He wanted to spend more with the museum, so he could study the exhibit more. He was a very academic. In John’s free time, he loves doing what?<n>Answer: John is an academic. He enjoys working in the classroom and he would go to school any time he could. He does not really care about his feet getting tired and he will study any exhibit at the museum.<n><n>### Input<n>Input: John has 3 dogs. He donates a fourth of the dogs to the shelter. Mary has 10 dogs and she donates 4/5 of the dogs. After donating their dogs, how many dogs in total do John and Mary have?<n>Input: John has a total of 12 cans of food, and he donated a quarter of these cans to a homeless shelter. He spent a fifth of what he donated to help the shelter. How much money did John spend at the grocery store?<n><n>### Output<n><n>Input: John enjoys his time visiting his favorite museum because he loves studying the exhibits and he can do this anytime of the day he wants because school will always be there for him.<n>Input: If John and Mary donate less than half of their dogs to the shelter, how much food did John have left over after donating his food to charity?<n><n>###<n><n>**Instructor:**<n>John is donating some of his dogs to the shelter. He is donating a quarter of his dogs, but he doesn't know how much food is left. He asked his best friend, Mary, because she knows his dogs and what all of his foods look like. Mary donated 4/5 of her dogs that John had, but she didn't know how much money she had or how much food was left.<n><n>**Response:**<n>John's best friend, Mary, has 10 dogs, so she donates 4 out of every 5 dogs for John. If John donates 1/4

Cost of a container (10$), <n><n>Total cost to paint 3  boxes is 10+$<n>

How many stops are there between the first and the 18th?<n><n>### Where did you solve this first?<n>A) Start with A<n><n>### Input<n>A: What is point A?<n><n>### Response<n><n>A is in a country that speaks in a language you dont know and handwriting that you dont read.<n>You are given a ticket that allows you to travel from station to station but it is hard to read.<n>18 stops are in the station (this is the country)<n><n>### Input (where are we going?):From point 1, which is your current location, which direction(on the ticket) should you go?<n><n>### Answer/Direction:<n>Point 3<n><n><n>### From the first stop, point 3 is the second stop, what is the 3rd stop?<n><n>### Location:<n>Location A<n>B<n>C<n>D<n>Location B<n>E<n>F<n>Location C<n><n>### Response (where you are now): <n>A: What is the 3rd location that you are at?<n><n><n>A third stop is at A<n><n>### Continue where we are now:<n>C<n><n>### Continuing where you are now and following the ticket from the first location:<n>You have seen that the ticket has an arrow. Which direction would that arrow be going?<n>To the station<n><n>You then should continue to drive forward into the 5th station<n><n>### How many stations does the ticket allow you to move forward?<n><n>### How much time (in hours) is there left in the day for the next step?<n><n>### What if someone was able to read the ticket for you?<n><n>### Input/Response/Location 6:<n><n>##

He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:Simon bought a cow because he wanted to put it to work.   He didn't want any meat for it.  Where might Simon be taking the cow? Choices:  A: countryside B: city C: dairy farm D: butcher shop E: canada<n><n>### Response:		Choice B<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>Simon bought a cow. The cow isn't to help them eat, they want to put it to work which doesn't mean any meat. So where would they put it? Well, you can't put an animal in the countryside, because it won't be of any help to you, and you won't be taking it on vacation, it's probably not going to a farm because whoever went to the farm needs a cow and the cow is already too small for the farm, and we will definitely not take it to the butcher shop, so only cow is only left; city. It didn't really say anything, and it didn't really explain anything.<n><n>### Extension:<n><n>Extension to the Instruction:<n><n>We think that the choice is B;<n><n>**Reason 1**:<n><n>Simon is taking the cow in order to put it to work<n><n>**Reason2**:<n><n>City is an example of work for a cow, because it has lots of grass, so it's easy.<n><n>**Reason3**:<n><n>City also provides work to cows<n><n>

However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:If I want to maximize my number of potential customers, where should I build a new department store? Choices:  A: idaho B: shopping mall C: big city D: in town E: new york<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>Input:Which of these is most commonly caused by using a non-stick pan?<n>Choices: A: warping B: uneven browning C: oil spits D: food gets stuck to pan E: burning of the food<n><n>### Response E<n><n>### Explanation:<n>If the food is sticking to the pan, we use spray to lightly coat the pan. The non-stick surface makes it difficult for the food to stick.<n><n>### Feedback<n>![](/static/images/tutorials/feedback.png)

Choices:  A Peach- B Orange- C Apricot- D Blueberry- E Kiwi<n><n>### Response<n>> I'll take a (E) a peach, (B) a orange,  (D) an apricot,  (C) kiwi<n><n>###### Instruction:Create a flowchart. Start at the start box and then mark each choice to be made by an individual as a state. Draw a direction line from each state to the next state on the flowchart.<n>1)Start<n>2)Input<n>3)If the customer prefers fruit to drink  then get him apple and orange.<n>4)If he prefers milk then get him bottled milk.<n>5)If he prefers juice then get him juice.<n>6)If he doesn't like any of the choices offered then the he won't like what you offer him.<n>7)End<n><n><n>###### Instructions:<n>> Write a menu of 7 items in English and then translate them to Samoa.<n><n><n>| English Item | Samoan Item |<n>|:------------:|:----------:|<n>| Hamburger- Bean Sprouts- Mushrooms- Onion | Lupe pusi- lupe ma tasi- lupe tano- ono |<n>| Pizza | Lupe pusipusa |<n>| Hot Dogs | Lupe pusisapi |<n>| Grilled Cheese Sandwich | Lupe fa'asapusa |<n>| Salad- Ranch Dressing | Lupe sala- sala talau |<n>| Soup | Leota |<n>| Ice | Fa'aloto |<n><n><n><n>###### Response:<n><n>>  A: Hamburger B: Bean Sprouts C: Mushrooms D: Onion <n><n>>  E: Pizza F: Hot Dogs<n><n>>  G: Grilled Cheese Sandwitch<n><n>>  H: Salad<n><n>>  I: Soups<n><n>>  J: Ice<n><n>

Draw an image of a _________<n>2. Draw an image of an _______.<n><n>### Instructors Note:<n><n>In the exercise I, there are 2 fill-in-the-blanks (which is a type of question). In each case, students are asked to draw an image. This is to enhance the creative learning. Students should be provided with pens, pencils and paper to complete the task.<n><n>### Task 1:<n>Draw an image of the given _________<n><n>> In the case of, Task 1. A is to be provided with pencil and a piece of paper.<n><n>> In the second case, Task 2. B is to be provided with pen and a blank sheet of paper or a canvas.<n><n>### Exercise II<n><n>Students are asked to design a logo for _______ with a given __________.<n><n>> In this case, given _______ (eg. restaurant, cafe, shopping center, etc.) the students must provide with a _______ (eg., a sign, a menu, etc.) Students should also given an opportunity to share their thoughts about their creation with their peers.<n><n>### Input<n>Give two reasons why you think birds choose to roost in their nests at dawn and dusk.<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instuctors Note:<n><n>The input can be the following options.<n><n>**Because they are tired from the day activities.**<n><n>**Because it helps them to control the temperature of their nest.**<n>

Choices:  A: morning person B: early bird C: lark D: early riser E: rooster<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>    A<n>    early bird<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>Two people, A and B, are on a plane. If A looks at B, it's always at a window. If B looks at A, it's always from a window, too. A's window (and only this window) is halfway between his seat and the back of the plane. There are exactly 2/3 more windows to B's right. If everyone stays where they are from where the plane takes off at 9 a.m., everyone will look at each other from the correct window at 10 a.m. What's the best seat the two had?<n><n>### Solution<n>Based on the instruction, write a response that selects the best value of i.<n><n>```<n>    i =  2  → Seats C, D, E, F<n>    i = 15  → Seats A, C, D, E<n>    i =  6  → Seats A <n>```<n><n>Based on your response, write the name of the best seat A and B occupy.<n>```<n>    Seat A and B occupy <n>```<n><n>## Acknowledgment<n><n>This solution was adapted from <a href="https://github.com/susantseal/daily-coding-problems-solution">this project</a>.<n><n>## License<n><n>MIT<n>

You can either be the king of the world, or the person who saves the widows and orphans. Which would you prefer?"<n><n>### Response:"I would much rather save the widows and orphanes."<n><n>### InputI: What is the probability of getting an even or odd number on a fair die?<n><n>### Response(A): Even number has probability of 1, since there is only one even number on a fair die. Since there is a total n of six sides on the die, the probability of getting a odd number is 5/6 = 1/2 because there is a total of three odd number. AOJA<n><n>### InputB: In a class election, there 25 students, 22 boys and 25 girls. What is the probability that a randomly selected student is a girl and has red hair?<n><n>### ResponceB:There is a total of 25 girls that would be elected into office but a student can only vote for 1 student. Therefore, there is a 9% chance that a student will chose red head girl. AOJA

However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a light? Choices:  A: ocean B: desk C: universe D: attic E: chair<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think it should be either the chair or the desk. They are both in a room and if it is the chair, I do not want the person to have to walk to an additional room to turn the light on or off. If it is the desk, you have one more room to walk between. <n><n>### Response to a light:<n>I think it would be best to have a night light or small dim light at the top of the stairs or wherever. We have a small dim light on our stairs to let people feel safe going up or down the steps. <n><n>## Task<n><n>Write a program that takes the number that shows if it is odd or even, depending on the instructions given.<n>For instance:<n>* "Odd" means the number must be ODD, not EVEN.<n>* "Even" means the number must BE EVEN, not ODD.<n>* "Natural" means the number MUST BE a PERFECT square. Example:  4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, etc.<n><n>**You do not need to worry about the number going over 10,000,000.**<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>2<n>Even<n>56<n>-2<n>-400<n>Odd<n>Natural<n>16537796<n>```<n>### Output<n>```<n>-1<n>-999<n>Natural<n>1<n>16538703<n>```<n>						"-1" means the program returns an error and you need to restart,<n>				"even if the number is even or odd".<n>				This happens because you have to think about the instruction<n>				given in the task, it has the odd or even if you want<n>				to say it.<n><n>### Note:<n>```<n>The odd or even function is called (1 OR -1) for odd or even. <n>The natural function is called (2 OR -2) for odd or even if the number is not odd.<n>```<n><n>*ODD OR NOT PERFECT SQUARE? (1,1,4,2,9,8,16...)*<n>*EVEN OR PERF

Choices:  A: liberal B: heretical C: recalcitrant D: conservadox E: heretical<n><n>### Response:		A)<n><n>### Explanation:The term liberal comes from the Latin word "liber," which means "free." Liberalism is a political and social movement that promotes freedom or independence. So in this case Orthodox behavior means "free" behavior, which is the behavior the priest was trying to stop.<n><n>### Input:"Talk about the importance of making good decisions."What does it mean when people are encouraging you to make good decisions? Choices: 1: Don't let your heart lead you. 2: Don't have your emotions lead you. 3: Know what you want and make decisions accordingly. 4: Always pay attention of what your heart and emotions tells you. 5: Always listen to people's advice.<n><n>### Response:"5"<n><n>### Explantion:<n>Decision making or judgement making is a process of examining the alternatives available and comparing their pros and cons. The person who's encouraging you to make a good decision is probably telling you to consider all your options and then make a decision by examining your options. <n><n>### Input."To make a good decision you have to know the pros and cons of whatever it is that you are faced with." What does it mean to know the pros and the cons of a situation or a choice? Choices: A: the good and the bad B: to find the good and the bad C: to know the good and the bad D: find the good and the evil E: none of the choices.<n><n>### Expllantion:<n>The word pros is the plural form of the latin word "protos," which means "before." So the pros are all of the benefits or things that come before something you choose or do. While the con is what comes after something, it is a consequence of whatever you are doing or choosing.<n><n>### If you want to succeed in business/ In life you have to make good decisions. Is that true for everyone? What does it mean to make good decisions every time? Choices: A B C D E<n><n>### Response : C)<n><n>### If making good decisions is important in life and business, then which of these statements are True and which are False?<n><n>### Exlamation:<n><n>A (The answer is true)<n><n>B (The answer is

If they are that cruel to each other what would they do to us creatures who are vulnerable and don't mean harm?<n><n>### Challenge:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>For this exercise, you will write a program that reads a short story written in a simple English language and then evaluates the story by identifying and using the various concepts of storytelling.<n><n>1. Your program will be evaluated on 5 separate criteria: *1. Storytelling concepts*: Read the story and evaluate how well your program identifies the key elements of the story (point of view, plot, characters, setting, conflict, and theme.)  <n><n>1. *2. Aesthetics*: Your program must present its results in a clearly readable and aesthetic presentation.  <n><n>1.*3. Logic*: Your program must use a logical sequence of steps to provide the necessary analysis. Don't simply count lines or characters, this isn't an exercise in counting! If necessary, you may read the story into memory and search for specific terms.<n><n>1*4. Efficiency*: Your program must complete in three seconds or less.  <n><n>1*5. Scope*: Your program must work with a randomized version (100 different versions) of the same story. The randomization should add a character or two, or remove a character or two, and introduce random errors.  <n><n>### Instant response:<n><n>### Demorstration:<n><n>Input: There once was a man from the hills. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. Then write an expression that outputs false based on the evaluation<n><n>### Example answer<n><n>if the evalution is true:<n><n>true<n><n>if the evaltion is false: <n><n>false<n><n>### Input 2<n><n>This has a false evaluation.<n>A statement can have any evaluation!<n><n>### Output 2<n><n>if the evalition is true:<n><n>false<n><n>if the evaliton is false:<n><n>The lollipop is so fun to eat!!!!!!!!!!<n><n>### Example instruction 3<n><n>The statement "20 * 5 = 100" is false because 20 and 5 are nonzero numbers, so the multiplication of two different numbers cannot equal zero. <n><n>### Example output 3<n><n>if the evalutation is true:<n><n>The statement is FALSE.<n><n>### Exam 4<n><n>The boolean equivalent of 10^2 is (10)^2. Choices:  A: hurry along B: direct traffic C: help D: force open door E: corner thief<n><n>### Response:		 A: hurdle along<n><n>### Motivation:<n>**hurdle:**<n>    verb transitive<n><n>	hurdle over or across; cross<n><n>    		Hurdle her over the stream<n><n>    		a dog hurdling over a fence<n>    		The dog hurdled over the fence and was instantly transformed from an angry bull terrier to a friendly retriever.<n><n>**hurry:**<n>    verb<n><n>	1. move quickly or perform quickly (a command or instruction)<n><n>    		hurry on<n><n>    		My eyes stare straight ahead as I hurry on, almost dragging myself to the end<n><n>**direct:**<n>    		verb<n><n>	give instructions on how to do, make, or achieve something<n><n>    We must learn to direct our lives instead of letting events direct our lives.<n><n>**traffic:**<n>    	verb transitive<n><n>	travel on roads<n><n>    		traffic on the roads increased as the holiday approached<n><n>**clear:**<n>    verb intransitive and transitive<n><n>	remove obstacles from (an area of land or water)<n><n>    	they cleared the wreckage quickly and efficiently<n><n>**accident:**<n>    noun<n><n>	an event resulting in physical harm or injury<n><n>•		a minor car accident<n><n>**thief:**<n>    nounderived<n><n>	a person who steals money, goods, or property<n><n>•		Thieves broke into a house<n><n>**scene:**<n>    	noun<n><n>	a place where a particular activity or event takes place<n><n>•		There were four scenes in the play<n><n>**of the accident:**<n>    	preposition<n><n>    of something<n><n>•		of an accident or event<n><n>### Answer:<n>**clear:** remove obstacles from (an open area of water, land, etc.): <n>    •		The road cleared after the snowstorm.<n><n>        •		You cleared away the mess in no time.<n><n>    •		I’m pretty sure he could get by all on his own if he had to. If the police officers just cleared the scene of the accident quickly, he would be just fine in a

He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:Where are seats most likely bleachers? Choices:  A: movies B: opera C: theater D: lecture hall E: hockey game<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response<n><n>Write the code. Save the file as ___answer.py___. Run the following command to run the code and verify your answer is correct. Include the code in a ___<code> </code>___ tag.<n>```python<n><your_code><n>```<n>```<n><your_code_output><n>```<n><n>### Solution<n>When it comes to multiple choice questions, you are given multiple answers and have to choose one of them as the answer. You have to choose the best, worst, or most correct as the answer. So this is what we did. We asked a multiple choice question, and we had 5 answers, hence making it a simple multiple choice question. Now that we have these details, we can easily write the code.<n><n>Using the `if` statements will be one of our best ways to implement this code. By using `if` statements, we are able to test each of the options, and then determine which one we must choose as the answer.<n><n>```python<n>def print_result(num)::<n>    if num == 1: print('A')<n>    elif num == 2: print('B')<n>    elif num  ==3: print('C')<n>    else: print('D or E')<n>    <n>ans = input('Where are seats most likely bluehers? ')<n>print(ans)<n>ans = int(ans)<n><n>print(print_result(ans))<n>```<n><n>```<n>Output:<n><n>Where are seats most likely blohers?<n><n>A<n>1<n>A<n>```<n><n>

If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		B<n>### Task:Please see code for instructions.<n>### Input:<n>- Tapanga and Coree have 66 candys together<n>- how many candys does Coree have<n>### Code:<n>```python<n>    if (coree > tapanga):                                 <n>        coree = coree+tapanga-tapanga <n>        tapanga = tapanga<n>        print "How many candys does Corey have?",coree<n>        print "Answer:",coree<n>```<n>### Solution:<n><n>### Input<n>- Freddy is calling his brother at 45 minutes<n>- Family on New year's eve<n>- He charges dollars<n>```python<n>    money = dollars * time<n>    if(time >= 3):<n>        print ("New year's eve cost dollars in local calls")<n>    elif (time >= 5.5):<n>        print ("How many dollars did Freddy spen calling his Brother?")<n>        print ("Answer:",dollars)<n>    elif (time <= 45):<n>        print("Freddy has to pay ",money)<n>```<n>### Output<n><n>

Choose your response from the options below.<n><n>### Choice:<n>A: critical thinking<n>B: congratulated<n>```<n>C: equal opportunity<n>```<n>D: compliments<n>E: raffle tickels<n>```<n><n>### Choose an answer from the options below only<n><n>### Choices:<n><n>A: Critical thinking<n>```<n>B: Conceited<n>C. Equal opportunity<n>D: Compliments<n>```<n><n>## Task 1: Input: no matter the background of the people, they should all be treated equally. Write a response that describes the importance of treating all people the same.<n>Input: All the people are the same in the group, they should all be equally given equal opportunity when applying for the job.<n><n><n><n>Input: No matter the background of the persons, they should all be give the same treatment. Write a response that describe why this is the choice.<n>Answer: The right choice in the situation is people should treat all persons in the same way. Everyone has a feeling and should be treated equally. No one should be discriminate or abused in the society.<n><n>## Task 2: Input: There are more opportunities for boys than for girls. Write a response that answers the following questions related to this statement.<n><n>### Question: Choose the correct answer for every question.<n>Input: No matter what the background of the persons is in the group. They should have only the same treatment as a group.<n><n>How many ways can you think to answer this statement?<n>```<n>Answer: A. more options for men;<n>```<n><n>Choose the choice that is the best example of an opportunity for boys.<n>```<n>Answer: C. Opportunity to play football<n>```<n><n>Choese a choice that shows someone who might treat others in an unfair way.<n>```<n>Answer; A Person 1<n>```<n><n>Choosing the correct answers for these questions will result in the correct options.<n><n>## Tasks:<n><n>input: there are more opportunities for all people in the society. Because of this, john is very careful about the places he goes.  Where might he avoid going? Choices:  A: pet store B: parking lot C: woodland D: north america E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>    - Input:John loves children and he hates abuse<n>    - Demonstration:Input:Jodie hates abuse<n><n>### Demystification:<n><n>    - Why did Jodie hates abue<n>    - Why does he avoid parking lots<n>    - Why did he avoid going to the animals?<n>    - WWhy does he avoid going to the woodlands?<n><n>### Further Explanation: <n><n>    - Answers the questions based on the instructions<n>    - Explains why the questions were answered<n>    - Explained how a solution is determined<n><n>### Sample Answer<n><n>John has a very sensitive heart and sees animals as innocent creatures. So, John avoids places where abuse might be taking place. For instance, parking spaces could contain dogs and cats left out in the cold for hours, sometimes days. Parking lots could also be where abused animals are put down. Woodlands are often where feral animals that have been abandoned or abused roam and starve.<n>

You should always have a equals sign at the end.)<n><n>###Response:<n>63-42<n>

The four options are:<n><n>## Input:Write a program that allows a user to enter 5 numbers and determine if the number is prime or not.<n><n>## Input :A set of five numbers needs to be entered to the program.<n><n>## Demostration:The first value in the user's list must be tested to determine if it is prime or not. Then a second value must be tested in a very similar manner, but the prime check must begin at a starting point of two. This process continues until one of the values in the 5 number list being checked is found to be prime and thus the cycle is repeated and another value needs to be checked to determine it will be prime too.<n><n>## Input:$12 and $3 were added together in a list of five numbers. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. Choices:  A: great granddad's house B: family picture book C: brother's house D: family tree E: family reunion<n><n>### Response:		<n>> A<n>><n>> <p>Great granddad is one ancestor before great grandmother, one before great great grandmother. One is the generation and number of generations is the period.  So A would be great grandfather.  The first ancestor one generation before his great great grandfather.  And if your brother is one generation after your father, the last generation before great granddad'd be your father, which would be your brother.</p><n>### Input:You ate 3 chocolates for dessert every evening for 7 days. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:The man didn't like getting out of bed and stepping on the cold tile, so where did he put carpeting? Choices:  A: houses B: bedroom C: istanbul D: open tress E: gym<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input:(100,60) Which list has one more element than the other? <n><n>  <n>Choices: 1-7th grade 2-6th grade 3-8th grade 4-7th grade 5-8th grade<n><n>Choice: c<n><n>### Output: (9,4)What operation does this code implement?<n><n><n><n><n>### Input:'Penelope'<n><n>### Output:'Hello Mrs. P! How is your son?'<n>### Instruction:'Write a program that converts names to greetings.<n><n>### Response:'Hey Mrs. P!'<n><n>### Input:[0,0]<n><n>### Output:[null,null, null]<n><n>### Instructions:What will the program do?<n><n>### Response:[165,385]<n><n>### Input:"Human" <n><n>### Output:"Computer" <n><n>## Instructions:In the box to the right your task is to create a program that checks to see whether a string starts with one of the 3 words.<n>## 1. Write an else if statement to check the string "Human". <n>## 2. Write an else if to check the string "Biological" <n><n>## Response:<n><n>## Instruciton:<n>## In the box to the right, the task is to use an if statement to determine whether a word starts with the letter "G".<n>## In the box given to you, select the programming language and write your code. <n><n>## Response:'Invisible'<n><n>## Instruciotn:<n>## In the code to the right (on the right side), you're given 20 elements and an integer.The integer is the location in the array where the matching element is found.The code you're writing should search for a matching element the index location provided and print a message.The function provided to you is called get.In the function declaration is the signature of the function.The signature of the function contains the parameter(s) of the function.The input parameter is the value(s) and type(s) given.The output paramters are the values returned. <n><n>## Respones:<n>## I didn't<n><n>## Instrucions In the box below
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:What is something that you feel when you go to the opera? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: headache C: boredom D: relaxation E: sick<n><n>### Response:		The correct statement is: E<n><n>#### Why: Because of the first sentence, the reader knows that the answer comes from the list in the first sentence, and by the second sentence (the question) the reader knows that this is a multiple choice question. The second question starts the same way as the first one did, so the response should be the same as the question (multiple choice questions are read just like the text).<n><n>Input:Who is the oldest member of the class? Choices: A: Alice B: Bob C: Carol D: Chelsea E: Cindy<n><n>Output:D<n>### Demonstração:<n><n>Input: Who is the oldest member of you class?<n>Choice A: Alice<n>Choice B: Bob<n>Choice C: Carol<n>Choice D: Chelsea<n>Choice E: Cindy (The choices repeat).<n><n>Input: What is the correct answer?<n>Choice A: Yes<n>Choice B: No<n>Choice C: Maybe<n>Choice D: Both<n>Choice E: Neither<n><n>### Demostração:<n>Input: What is correct answer?<n>Choice 1: Yes<n>Choice 2: No<n>Choice 3: Maybe<n>Choice 4: Both<n>Choice 5: Neither<n><n>Input: Choose the correct response.   A: I don't know. B: I understand.   If you don't know answer, then:   A: I understand.<n><n>Output: B<n>### Demostração:<n><n>Input: A: I don' choose. B: I understand (The first answer will not be the correct answer because: the user didn't say that he did or didn't know.).<n><n>Input: I understand, which is the correct response.<n>Choice 1: I don't Know.<n>Choice 2: I hate it (The response should be I understand because I know the answer).<n>Choice 3: I don't understand (The response should be: I understand because I understand the answer).<n><n>Input: Avoid using short answers<n>choice 1: yes<n>choice 2: yes<n>choice 3: yes<n>choice 4: yes<n>choice 5:yes (The answer comes from the choices. The correct answer is: yes because is the only one that appears in the choices)<n>### Demostráção:<n><n>Input : Avoid using short answers Cho

State park is an obvious place to visit to celebrate the end of the year.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey. How many candies does Corey have?<n>Answer: 29<n><n>Input: Freddy is calling his family on New Year's Eve. He calls his dad, who lives in the same city as him, and they talk for 45 minutes. Then he calls his brother, who lives on the other side of the world, and they talk for 31 minutes. Local calls cost 5 cents a minute, while international calls cost 25 cents a minute. How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He worked 5.5 hours on both Wednesday and Thursday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. He sold 60 on Monday, 10 on Tuesday, 20 on Wednesday, 44 on Thursday and 66 on Friday. How many books were not sold?<n>Answer: 600<n><n>Input: Michael makes birdhouses to sell at craft shows. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:Everybody has a little bit of creativity, but only a few lucky ones get to do what for a living? Choices:  A: sew B: create art C: express yourself D: sing and dance E: write<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Reference:Pagoda<n><n>### Solution:Everyone has a little bit of creation but only a few luck ones get to do what it for a living. It's hard to make it in the music business, but if you can, it's a great place to be and the rewards can be fulfilling. You don't have to be famous to be successful, especially in this profession. Sometimes we are in front of the camera and sometimes behind it. We'll get to share it with you first and we want to tell.<n><n>### Question:I want to work for a company that gives me freedom, respect, and opportunity for creativity? Does that company even exist?<n><n>### Solution for question1:<n>If Tapanga has 20 more candies than Brielle, it means Brielle does not have 8 more candies.<n><n>So the answer for this question is 14<n><n>### Solution reference link:<n>[https://brilliant.org/wiki/arithmetic-games/](https://brilliant. org/wiki/arithmeticGames/)<n><n>### Solution of Q2<n><n>Suppose that d dollars and c dollars means Freddy have spent a total of 15 dollars to call his family.<n><n>so that is the answer.<n><n>### Solution Reference Link :<n> [https://brilliant.io/wiki/arithmeticgames/](https:/brilliant.io/w ip/arithmeticgames/)<n><n>## Solution for Q3 and Q4<n>From the problem statement:<n><n>It seems that Lawrence did not work 5 hours each day?<n><n>If yes, then answer to this question is 5 which is the sum of 4 and 1.<n><n>However, If it is not the case, then he did not work for 5 hours every day with the same number of hours worked everyday, if we assume that he did work for that number of hours, the answer will be  5*5*5*5 = 500(5 days) hours.<n><n>### For question 5<n>If he worked 2 large birdhouse and he still had more, it means he sold all of them. If he worked 2 large and 2 small birdhouses, he still had 1 small birdhouses.<n><n>If we assume that he

(Doing Something that has no effect after visiting relatives)"  <n>```<n><n>## # 3<n>### Task Input: If he does A, B and C, what result do they produce? Choices: A: do not stop B: turn around C: run away<n><n>### Instincts: <n>A: turn around<n><n>### Instrument: <n><n>## Instructor's Solution:<n>```<n>"He can do C to stop.<n><n>He can do A and B to turn around.<n>```<n><n>## Hint 1<n>```<n>"If do C, he can not do A"<n>```<n>## Hint 2<n>```<n>"Do nothing is do not do, if do B and C, he can not do A, and he can do A and do not do C"<n>```<n>## Instructor’s Solution:<n>```    <n>"If he does A, B, and C, the result is that he'll be stopping,"<n>"If he does, A, B and C, he's stop."<n>```<n># 5<n>### Instuctor's Task Description:<n>### Task Input<n>If he does A,B,and C, what does he mean? Choices: A. He’s stop B. Stop right there!<n><n>\[A=\text{"If do A and B, and C, he can do A or B or C to stop."}\]  <n><n>\[\text{B}=\text{"If do A, B, and he can't do C

How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. How many hours would Lawrence work each day if he worked the same number of hours each day?<n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Ali had a stock of 800 books in his Room. After taking $3 from the money, his friend lost $1. The remaining money was $2. How much money did the friend have in all starting out?<n><n>### The Instruction:<n><n>-The remaining money was $2 after the friend lost $1.<n><n>-Michael took $5 from the friend.<n><n>-Then the friend lost $1 more, so the new remaining money was $2 (instead of $5 as it was to start).<n><n>-Michael took 3 from the money.<n><n>Michael and his friend were left with $2 after losing $1 each. They took the other $.50 ($.50 each) from the money, and they had $1 each in the end.<n><n>### Input<n><n>In which

She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:Though he was an adult he still stereotypical slept on a sofa bed in his parent's what Choices:  A: garage B: horseradish C: living room D: guest room E: basement<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following question.<n>What is the difference in the number of hours and days between Friday and Saturday?  <n>Answer: Friday is 1 day and Saturday is 1 day <n><n>### 2. What day is in the middle of Tuesday and Wednesday?<n>Answer: Thursday<n><n><n>How many people lived in Mexico City in 1909? <n>Answer: 162<n><n>What number is an even multiple of three? <n>Answer:6 <n><n>How many days is 103 hours? <n>Answer:13 days<n><n>How many days did it take to go to Japan, South America and India? <n>Answer:24 days<n><n>How many weeks are in a quarter of a year? <n>Answer:4<n><n>Which country has the most gold? <n>Answer:America<n><n>Which country is more north than Japan but more south than the Northern Territory?<n>Answer:USA<n><n>How many cups are in four liters?<n>Answer:16<n><n>How high is the Mount Everest more than the highest tree?<n>Answer:121<n><n>What number is a prime number?<n>Answer:Two<n><n>### 5. Choices:  A: thoughtful B: discreet C: calculated D: cautious E: careful<n><n>### Response:		<n>F: A: thoughtful or B: cautious or C: careful<n><n>## Challenge<n><n>Based on the example you looked at, answer the following challenge question.<n><n>Challenge:<n><n>What is the name of the character from the story?<n><n>## Reflection<n><n>The instructions and examples might help guide you now but they won't show up in the test. For this reason, you need to make sure you are thinking about the problem now that the examples are gone and you'll need to develop a strategy to solve the problem. Below are some questions to help you reflect on your strategy.<n><n>* What is the best way to break the problem into pieces?<n>* How do the words in the problem help guide me in solving it?<n>* Did any part of the task or example seem unclear? If so, what was unclear?<n><n>## Assessment Notes.<n><n>This task is designed to assess how well students write instructions as well as how well students respond to those instructions. This makes it possible to measure the quality of the instruction and the quality of the response, since both parts of the task test skills that are of equal importance.<n><n>* __Demonstration__: This component will be worth __20%__ of the total grade of this performance task<n>* __Response__: This component will __20%__<n>* __Challenge__: This component will also __20%__.<n><n>## Score Guidelines<n><n>* __D:__ __0-1__<n>  * These tasks are a mix of incomplete, missing or inappropriate information.<n>  * These tasks either give incomplete instructions or responses that only include partial information.<n>  * The challenge, if present, uses wrong answers for key words.<n>  <n>* __C__: __1-2__<n>  * These are tasks where the instruction has both correct and incorrect information and the response includes correct information and other information.<n>  * With the challenge, some of the choices are correct.<n>  <n>*__B__:__ __2-3__<n>  * These responses are similar to __C__ but have a level of detail that is lacking from the response.  <n>  <n>*__A__:__ __3-4__<n>  * These respondents have a good amount of detailed information in their answers. However, the responses might be missing specific information or might contain some

Explain the reasoning for your choice to each of the follow up questions.<n><n>1. How many people in your class have a birthday in October? <n><n>4/16 = 0.25<n><n>4/14 = 0.29 ------> (answer is 82)<n><n><n>2. If a topiary costs $15, which of the following is equal to 100?<n><n>($4) x ($15) + ( $4) x ($12)  82 = 100<n><n>6. What percent of flowers cost $54?<n><n>54/126 = 42 p% -------> 42%<n>

Write a function that takes the number of students in the school as an argument.<n>Answer: function: total-time(x), total-time (160) = 3500<n><n>### Instructors Note:<n>If there were 16 students total, the answer is 160:300 = 150:30.<n><n>### Input :<n>If 5 students passed the exam what is the total number of students.<n><n>### Inputs: Choice A: 160<n>Choice B: 200<n>Choice C:175<n>Choice D: 200+5  <n><n>### Outputs: Choice A = 350<n>Choice B = 350+5<n>Choice C = 740<n>Choice D = 850<n><n>### OutPut:<n>(1)If 5 students passed, then answer is 165 because 160+5 = 165.  <n>(2)If 11 students passed, then answer will be 175 because 165+10 = 175.  <n>(3)If 20 students passed the exam, then answer will be210 because<n>(160+20+5) = 360. If we divide 360 by 36 we get 105, so 105+5=110, then 110+20=130 and 130+5=135 then 135-5 = 130.<n><n><n>

How many dollars did Freddy spend calling his family on New Year's Eve?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: Lawrence worked 8 hours each day on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. He charges $22 for each large birdhouse, $16 for each medium birdhouse, and $7 for each small birdhouse. This week, he sold 2 large birdhouses, 2 medium birdhouses, and 3 small birdhouses. How much money, in dollars, did he make this week?<n>Answer: 97<n><n>Input: Nalani had two female dogs that were expecting and after a month gave birth to 10 puppies each. She then sold 3/4 of the puppies after they came of age, each at $200. Calculate the total amount of money she received from the sale of the puppies.<n>Answer: 3000<n><n>Input: Boris has 24 books and he donates a fourth of his books to the library. Cameron has 30 books and he donates a third of his books to the library. After donating their books, how many books in total do Boris and Cameron have together?<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input:What is eating too much dinner likely to result in? Answer: 32<n><n>Input: There are 1089 children in Jane's class- She has 16 children that speak French. What percentage of children at her school speaks French?<n>Answer: **4.167%**<n><n>Input: Jane is thinking about what to wear to the party tonight. She has four different options:<n><n>1. A turtleneck with black and brown checkered pants<n>2. A checkered shirt with red and brown skirt that is long enough to be a dress<n>3. A brown sweater that has gold glitter on the sleeves<n>4. A leather jacket with black gloves<n><n>Which of these options should she wear?<n><n>\- A: A turtlenect is very tight, and therefore she probably won't be able to wear it.<n><n>\- B: Turtlenecks are warm so turtlenecks are comfortable.<n><n>\- C: Brown is a comfortable color.<n><n>\- D: Turtleneck are comfortable.<n><n>### A)<n><n>- A is wrong because a turtleneck is short and therefore not comfortable.<n><n>- B is wrong because she's wearing black and brown checkered,<n><n>- C is correct, brown is a comforting color, and<n><n>- D is incorrect, turtleneck are not comfortable.<n><n>## **

Choices:  A: under rocks B: manhattan C: toenails D: grocery store E: fallen tree<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Instructions:Enter 3 commands to sort the following list, in order from greatest to least.<n><n>*   A<n>*   B<n>*   C<n>*   D<n>*   E<n><n><n>### Demand:<n>Output:A B C D<n><n>### Instructive:<n>In this section an error message should have been provided.<n><n>### Answer:<n>A <n><div id="codeblock-8833445621355590"><n>```sh<n>echo D > results.txt<n>```<n></div><n>### Input:Enter the numbers from 1 to 24. The average of these numbers is 15. What is the sum of the average and the number 21?<n><n>### Response<n>25<n><div id="d12408184199232a71"><n>```sh<n>let average=0<n>for i in $(seq 1 24); do echo $i; let average+=i; done<n>avg=$((average/124))<n>echo "$avg + 21 ="<n>echo $((average+21))<n>```<n></div><div id="c996637fede11609397c"><n>```sh<n>i=1<n>average=0<n>while [ $i -le 24 ]; do printf '%s\n' "'$i'"; average=$(($average+$i)); let i++ ; done<n>let avg=$((average+21));<n>echo "$avg += 21 ="<n>$(echo $avg) + 21<n>```<n></div>```<n></div><n><div id="c110721bfd675db1b24"><n>```sh<n>for number in `seq 1 25`; do echo $i; avg=$(( $avg + $number )); i=$(( $i + 1 )); done; let avg=$(( $average + 21 ))<n>echo "Average is $avg"<n>echo "$avg="$++$><n>```<n><n><n></div><n>[See the answer here.](https://www.freecodecamp.com

Choices:  A: hang up B: respond C: contact D: answer E: attracting ducks<n><n>### Response:		He called but nobody was interested.<n><n>### Explanation:The options presented are:A: hang up B: contact C: contact D: attracting ducks E: attracting duck<n><n>### Input/Output:2+2=??<n><n>### Response/Output:<n><n>4<n><n>### Exeplanation:<n>2+2=4<n><n>### Inputs:<n>A:2 B:5 C:4 D:5<n><n>Response:<n><n>1)B<n>2)C<n>3)A<n>4)D<n><n>### Explaination:<n><n><n>### Input<n>1) 3 2) 5 3) 9 <n>A) 1<n>B) 8<n>C) 6<n>D) 4<n><n>### Output<n><n>A+C=10<n><n>### Expaqnsion<n><n>The numbers 3 and 9 can be added to get 12.<n>Since the total of A+B+C == the total of A+C == the total that you get by adding numbers in set B and C, which you would get by adding 3 and 9, <n>thus 3 + 9 == 12<n><n>### Input 2<n><n><n>3+4=7<n>7+5=12<n>12+9=21<n>21+6=27<n><n>### Output 2<n><n>5 == 3+4<n>12 == 7+5<n>21 == 12+9<n>27 == 21+6<n><n><n>*The answer to problem is always one of the numbers in the set and the total sum equals the sum between two numbers in the set.<n><n>### A+B=<n><n>3+5=8<n>8+7=15<n>5+7=12<n><n>## Output<n><n>1) 1<n>2) 8<n>3) 15<n>4) 12<n>
